Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had an A a e i o u With an [eɪ] [eɪ] here and an [æ] [æ] there Here an  [eɪ] , there an [æ] Everywhere an  [eɪ], [æ] Old McDonald had a farm a e i o u And on his farm he had an e a e i o u With an [iː] [iː] here and an [ɛ] [ɛ] there Here an [i:] , there an [ɛ] Everywhere an [i:]  [ɛ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had an i a e i o u With an [aɪ] [aɪ] here and an  [ɪ] [ɪ] there Here an [aɪ] , there an [ɪ] Everywhere an  [aɪ]  [ɪ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had an O a e i o u With an [oʊ] [oʊ] here and an [ɒ] [ɒ] there Here an [oʊ] , there an [ɒ] Everywhere an [oʊ] , [ɒ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had a U a e i o u WIth a [juː] [juː] here and an [ʌ] [ʌ] there Here a [juː] , there an [ʌ] Everywhere a [juː] ,  [ʌ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u a e i o u

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which letters are vowels?
Options: A. a,e, i, o, y, B. a, e, u, s, o, C. a, e, c, u, i, D. a, e, i, o, u
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main theme of the song featured in the transcript? Options: A. Farm animals, B. Vowels, C. Alphabet, D. Numbers Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which vowels are mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. A, E, I, O, U, B. E, I, O, U, C. A, E, I, D. O, U, A Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the title of the song featured in the transcript? Options: A. The Vowel Song, B. A E I O U, C. Old McDonald, D. The Farm Song Correct Option: A
Question 4: How would you apply the concept of vowels in a real-world scenario? Options: A. When teaching children the alphabet, you would emphasize the importance of vowels., B. When writing a poem, you would focus on using only the vowels A, E, I, O, and U., C. When learning a new language, you would focus on pronouncing vowels correctly to improve your overall pronunciation and communication skills., D. When creating a song, you would use vowels to create a catchy melody. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the relationship between the vowels mentioned in the transcript and their corresponding pronunciations? Options: A. The vowels A, E, I, O, and U have unique pronunciations for each instance, and these pronunciations are demonstrated in the transcript., B. The vowels A, E, I, O, and U have the same pronunciation /eɪ/ in the transcript., C. The vowels A, E, I, O, and U have different pronunciations for each verse., D. The vowels A, E, I, O, and U have the same pronunciation throughout the transcript. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How would you synthesize the concept of vowels in a creative way? Options: A. Create a song that incorporates the sounds of different vowels, using their unique pronunciations to create a catchy and memorable melody., B. Write a poem that explores the different pronunciations of vowels., C. Develop a game that teaches children about the importance of vowels., D. Design a poster that showcases the different vowels and their corresponding pronunciations. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of the song in teaching the concept of vowels? Options: A. The song is highly effective in teaching the concept of vowels, as it uses repetition and catchy melodies to reinforce the unique pronunciations of each vowel., B. The song is somewhat effective in teaching the concept of vowels., C. The song is not effective in teaching the concept of vowels., D. The song is only effective for children. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the purpose of the repetition of vowels in the transcript? Options: A. To create a catchy melody, B. To emphasize the importance of vowels, C. To demonstrate the different pronunciations of vowels and reinforce their unique sounds., D. To create a sense of rhythm Correct Option: C
Question 9: How would you apply the concept of vowels in a language learning scenario? Options: A. Focus on learning the correct pronunciation of vowels to improve your overall pronunciation and communication skills., B. Focus on learning the correct spelling of vowels., C. Focus on learning the correct grammar of vowels., D. Focus on learning the correct vocabulary of vowels. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of the vowels A, E, I, O, and U in the English language? Options: A. They are the most commonly used vowels in the English language., B. They are the most difficult vowels to pronounce in the English language., C. They are the most important vowels in the English language, as they form the foundation of many words and are essential for effective communication., D. They are the vowels that are most commonly used in song titles. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: "Which vowels are mentioned in the transcript?" 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, "Which letters are vowels?" Both questions are asking about the identification of vowels, and the correct options (A. A, E, I, O, U in Question 2 and D. a, e, i, o, u in the ground truth MCQ) match the standard set of vowels in the English language.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had an A a e i o u With an [eɪ] [eɪ] here and an [æ] [æ] there Here an  [eɪ] , there an [æ] Everywhere an  [eɪ], [æ] Old McDonald had a farm a e i o u And on his farm he had an e a e i o u With an [iː] [iː] here and an [ɛ] [ɛ] there Here an [i:] , there an [ɛ] Everywhere an [i:]  [ɛ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had an i a e i o u With an [aɪ] [aɪ] here and an  [ɪ] [ɪ] there Here an [aɪ] , there an [ɪ] Everywhere an  [aɪ]  [ɪ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had an O a e i o u With an [oʊ] [oʊ] here and an [ɒ] [ɒ] there Here an [oʊ] , there an [ɒ] Everywhere an [oʊ] , [ɒ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u And on his farm he had a U a e i o u WIth a [juː] [juː] here and an [ʌ] [ʌ] there Here a [juː] , there an [ʌ] Everywhere a [juː] ,  [ʌ] Old McDonald had some vowels a e i o u a e i o u

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. one, B. two, C. three, D. four
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the temple of the fisherman, 
Quexo, the village shaman, looks out over the ocean and frowns. It’s a still morning–
unusually still, and the lack of wind is the latest 
in a series of troubling signs. The year is 1400 BCE. Quexo’s village sits in the dusty, 
treeless desert between the towering Andes 
and Pacific Ocean. The villagers live off the sea, 
harvesting reeds, drying them in the sun, 
and using them to build fishing boats. Every day in the summer, the men set out on these boats
to hunt shark and other fish while the women harvest 
shellfish and sea urchins. In winter, storms bring powerful waves,
which cross the vast ocean unobstructed to detonate on these shores. Most years, Quexo’s village catches 
more than enough fish. But this year, the winds have died 
and the fish have dwindled. Quexo has seen this pattern before: the fish disappear, 
then the violent rains arrive, causing flash floods that dissolve 
mud bricks and wash away settlements. He needs to stop the bad weather 
before the storms come— his only hope is a special ritual 
he’s been planning. Quexo spends much less time
in the ocean than the other villagers. He became a shaman after seeing 
a sign in the sea one morning— like his father and grandfather
before him. This morning, he walks to the nearby sacred mountain 
as the sun rises. There, he gathers ceremonial cactus 
and herbs like “horse tail,” “stonebreaker," and valerian, 
along with the mineral hematite. Back in the village, 
everyone is preparing to leave for a religious festival 
at a large temple inland. The festival marks the beginning of what
is usually the season of abundance, but with the signs pointing to storms,
Quexo isn’t feeling too celebratory. Whole families travel to the festival,
where they camp for a few days. They’ve packed seaweed, carved bones,
gourd bowls, reed mats, and other goods to trade 
in the market around the temple. Quexo inspects the goods to make 
sure everything is of the finest quality. He brings the herbs he gathered 
to trade for cinnabar, a mineral that comes 
from the highlands in the Andes. He needs cinnabar for his ritual 
to ward off the storms. Around lunchtime, the sprawling 
temple rises out of the desert ahead. People have come from all along 
the coast and the foothills. The women handle trade transactions—
they’re looking for cotton and ceramics. Men aren’t usually allowed 
to do the trading, but shamans are an exception. Though Quexo is a man, during rituals 
he becomes half man, half woman, and this ambiguity makes his role 
more flexible outside ceremonies too. Quexo can’t find any cinnabar 
in the market, so he heads to the main temple, dodging children playing in the plaza. He puts on his ceremonial garb: 
red face paint, earrings, and a necklace of shark’s teeth
and vertebrae. Inside, the ceremonies 
are already underway, and the shamans have drunk
the sacred cactus drink. Many of them are Quexo’s friends 
from festivals over the years, but he doesn’t see the mountain shamans 
who would have cinnabar. He begins to panic. If the highland shamans don’t show up, his only option will be to make 
the long walk into the mountains. It’s a dangerous journey 
that takes five days, precious time he doesn’t have to waste. But perhaps he has no choice. He refuses the sacred cactus 
and sets off toward the mountains. As he leaves the settlement behind,
he sees a group approaching. He recognizes them as highlanders
by their llamas. He dashes toward their shaman. Barely pausing to say hello, 
he offers him hematite, dried seaweed, and empty shells to grind up for lime
and chew with coca leaves. In return, the other shaman 
gives him the precious cinnabar. With the key to his ritual in hand, Quexo heads home to the temple 
of the fisherman in hopes of turning the tide.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cinnabar was exploited by ancient Peruvians in_______ mines
Options: A. Coastal, B. Amazonian, C. Highlan
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the village shaman in the story? Options: A. Quexo, B. The Fisherman, C. The Shaman of the Andes, D. The High Mountain Shaman Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary reason for Quexo's concern in the story? Options: A. The winds have died, and the fish have dwindled., B. The storms are approaching, and the villagers are not prepared., C. The villagers are not harvesting enough shellfish and sea urchins., D. The sacred cactus drink is not available. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the significance of the hematite in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for cinnabar., B. It is a key ingredient in the sacred cactus drink., C. It is a symbol of Quexo's status as a shaman., D. It is used to ward off the storms. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of Quexo's ritual? Options: A. To celebrate the beginning of the season of abundance., B. To ward off the storms and ensure a good harvest., C. To trade goods with the villagers., D. To become a shaman. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the role of the women in the story? Options: A. They are the leaders of the village., B. They are the ones who handle trade transactions., C. They are the ones who harvest shellfish and sea urchins., D. They are the ones who prepare the sacred cactus drink. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why is Quexo able to trade with the highland shaman? Options: A. Because he is a highland shaman himself., B. Because he has the sacred cactus drink., C. Because he has the hematite., D. Because he is a man and an exception to the rule. Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the significance of the cinnabar in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for other goods., B. It is a key ingredient in the sacred cactus drink., C. It is a symbol of Quexo's status as a shaman., D. It is used to ward off the storms. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the danger of Quexo's journey to the mountains? Options: A. It is a long and difficult journey., B. It is a journey that takes five days., C. It is a journey that takes him away from the village., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the result of Quexo's ritual? Options: A. The storms are still approaching., B. The fish have increased in number., C. The villagers are still preparing for the festival., D. The tide is turned, and the storms are warded off. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the significance of Quexo's role as a shaman? Options: A. It is a role that is limited to men., B. It is a role that is limited to women., C. It is a role that is flexible and allows for ambiguity., D. It is a role that is not important in the story. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

Although the question content is not identical, the intent and the options' focus on cinnabar make Question 7 the most similar. Question 7 asks about the significance of cinnabar in the story, and the correct option (D) states that it is used to ward off the storms. The ground truth MCQ asks about the location of cinnabar mines, but the correct option (C) also relates to the highlands, which is mentioned in the story as the source of cinnabar.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. But based on the available options, Question 7 is the closest match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the temple of the fisherman, 
Quexo, the village shaman, looks out over the ocean and frowns. It’s a still morning–
unusually still, and the lack of wind is the latest 
in a series of troubling signs. The year is 1400 BCE. Quexo’s village sits in the dusty, 
treeless desert between the towering Andes 
and Pacific Ocean. The villagers live off the sea, 
harvesting reeds, drying them in the sun, 
and using them to build fishing boats. Every day in the summer, the men set out on these boats
to hunt shark and other fish while the women harvest 
shellfish and sea urchins. In winter, storms bring powerful waves,
which cross the vast ocean unobstructed to detonate on these shores. Most years, Quexo’s village catches 
more than enough fish. But this year, the winds have died 
and the fish have dwindled. Quexo has seen this pattern before: the fish disappear, 
then the violent rains arrive, causing flash floods that dissolve 
mud bricks and wash away settlements. He needs to stop the bad weather 
before the storms come— his only hope is a special ritual 
he’s been planning. Quexo spends much less time
in the ocean than the other villagers. He became a shaman after seeing 
a sign in the sea one morning— like his father and grandfather
before him. This morning, he walks to the nearby sacred mountain 
as the sun rises. There, he gathers ceremonial cactus 
and herbs like “horse tail,” “stonebreaker," and valerian, 
along with the mineral hematite. Back in the village, 
everyone is preparing to leave for a religious festival 
at a large temple inland. The festival marks the beginning of what
is usually the season of abundance, but with the signs pointing to storms,
Quexo isn’t feeling too celebratory. Whole families travel to the festival,
where they camp for a few days. They’ve packed seaweed, carved bones,
gourd bowls, reed mats, and other goods to trade 
in the market around the temple. Quexo inspects the goods to make 
sure everything is of the finest quality. He brings the herbs he gathered 
to trade for cinnabar, a mineral that comes 
from the highlands in the Andes. He needs cinnabar for his ritual 
to ward off the storms. Around lunchtime, the sprawling 
temple rises out of the desert ahead. People have come from all along 
the coast and the foothills. The women handle trade transactions—
they’re looking for cotton and ceramics. Men aren’t usually allowed 
to do the trading, but shamans are an exception. Though Quexo is a man, during rituals 
he becomes half man, half woman, and this ambiguity makes his role 
more flexible outside ceremonies too. Quexo can’t find any cinnabar 
in the market, so he heads to the main temple, dodging children playing in the plaza. He puts on his ceremonial garb: 
red face paint, earrings, and a necklace of shark’s teeth
and vertebrae. Inside, the ceremonies 
are already underway, and the shamans have drunk
the sacred cactus drink. Many of them are Quexo’s friends 
from festivals over the years, but he doesn’t see the mountain shamans 
who would have cinnabar. He begins to panic. If the highland shamans don’t show up, his only option will be to make 
the long walk into the mountains. It’s a dangerous journey 
that takes five days, precious time he doesn’t have to waste. But perhaps he has no choice. He refuses the sacred cactus 
and sets off toward the mountains. As he leaves the settlement behind,
he sees a group approaching. He recognizes them as highlanders
by their llamas. He dashes toward their shaman. Barely pausing to say hello, 
he offers him hematite, dried seaweed, and empty shells to grind up for lime
and chew with coca leaves. In return, the other shaman 
gives him the precious cinnabar. With the key to his ritual in hand, Quexo heads home to the temple 
of the fisherman in hopes of turning the tide.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cinnabar was found by ancient Peruvians in_______ mines
Options: A. Coastal, B. Amazonian, C. Highland, D. Glaciers
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the village shaman in the story? Options: A. Quexo, B. The Fisherman, C. The Shaman of the Andes, D. The High Mountain Shaman Correct Option: A

The storms are approaching, and the villagers are not prepared., C. The villagers are not harvesting enough shellfish and sea urchins., D. The sacred cactus drink is not available. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the significance of the hematite in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for cinnabar., B. It is a key ingredient in the sacred cactus drink., C. It is a symbol of Quexo's status as a shaman., D. It is used to ward off the storms. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of Quexo's ritual? Options: A. To celebrate the beginning of the season of abundance., B. To ward off the storms and ensure a good harvest., C. To trade goods with the villagers., D. To become a shaman. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the role of the women in the story? Options: A. They are the leaders of the village., B. They are the ones who handle trade transactions., C. They are the ones who harvest shellfish and sea urchins., D. They are the ones who prepare the sacred cactus drink. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why is Quexo able to trade with the highland shaman? Options: A. Because he is a highland shaman himself., B. Because he has the sacred cactus drink., C. Because he has the hematite., D. Because he is a man and an exception to the rule. Correct Option: D

Question 8: What is the danger of Quexo's journey to the mountains? Options: A. It is a long and difficult journey., B. It is a journey that takes five days., C. It is a journey that takes him away from the village., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D

Question 10: What is the significance of Quexo's role as a shaman? Options: A. It is a role that is limited to men., B. It is a role that is limited to women., C. It is a role that is flexible and allows for ambiguity., D. It is a role that is not important in the story. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

Although the question content is not identical, the intent and the correct option's relationship to cinnabar are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks where cinnabar was found, and the correct answer is "Highland mines." Question 7 asks about the significance of cinnabar in the story, and while the options do not directly mention the location where cinnabar is found, the correct answer choice (D) implies that cinnabar is used for a specific purpose, which is related to its significance in the story. However, Question 3 and its correct answer choice (A) also imply a connection to cinnabar, stating that hematite is used to trade for cinnabar, and it mentions that cinnabar comes from the highlands in the Andes.

However, a more suitable generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ would be one that directly asks about the origin or source of cinnabar. Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the provided generated MCQs.

Given the available options, the closest match would be Question 3, as it indirectly provides information about the origin of cinnabar (the highlands in the Andes), which is the main intent of the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the temple of the fisherman, 
Quexo, the village shaman, looks out over the ocean and frowns. It’s a still morning–
unusually still, and the lack of wind is the latest 
in a series of troubling signs. The year is 1400 BCE. Quexo’s village sits in the dusty, 
treeless desert between the towering Andes 
and Pacific Ocean. The villagers live off the sea, 
harvesting reeds, drying them in the sun, 
and using them to build fishing boats. Every day in the summer, the men set out on these boats
to hunt shark and other fish while the women harvest 
shellfish and sea urchins. In winter, storms bring powerful waves,
which cross the vast ocean unobstructed to detonate on these shores. Most years, Quexo’s village catches 
more than enough fish. But this year, the winds have died 
and the fish have dwindled. Quexo has seen this pattern before: the fish disappear, 
then the violent rains arrive, causing flash floods that dissolve 
mud bricks and wash away settlements. He needs to stop the bad weather 
before the storms come— his only hope is a special ritual 
he’s been planning. Quexo spends much less time
in the ocean than the other villagers. He became a shaman after seeing 
a sign in the sea one morning— like his father and grandfather
before him. This morning, he walks to the nearby sacred mountain 
as the sun rises. There, he gathers ceremonial cactus 
and herbs like “horse tail,” “stonebreaker," and valerian, 
along with the mineral hematite. Back in the village, 
everyone is preparing to leave for a religious festival 
at a large temple inland. The festival marks the beginning of what
is usually the season of abundance, but with the signs pointing to storms,
Quexo isn’t feeling too celebratory. Whole families travel to the festival,
where they camp for a few days. They’ve packed seaweed, carved bones,
gourd bowls, reed mats, and other goods to trade 
in the market around the temple. Quexo inspects the goods to make 
sure everything is of the finest quality. He brings the herbs he gathered 
to trade for cinnabar, a mineral that comes 
from the highlands in the Andes. He needs cinnabar for his ritual 
to ward off the storms. Around lunchtime, the sprawling 
temple rises out of the desert ahead. People have come from all along 
the coast and the foothills. The women handle trade transactions—
they’re looking for cotton and ceramics. Men aren’t usually allowed 
to do the trading, but shamans are an exception. Though Quexo is a man, during rituals 
he becomes half man, half woman, and this ambiguity makes his role 
more flexible outside ceremonies too. Quexo can’t find any cinnabar 
in the market, so he heads to the main temple, dodging children playing in the plaza. He puts on his ceremonial garb: 
red face paint, earrings, and a necklace of shark’s teeth
and vertebrae. Inside, the ceremonies 
are already underway, and the shamans have drunk
the sacred cactus drink. Many of them are Quexo’s friends 
from festivals over the years, but he doesn’t see the mountain shamans 
who would have cinnabar. He begins to panic. If the highland shamans don’t show up, his only option will be to make 
the long walk into the mountains. It’s a dangerous journey 
that takes five days, precious time he doesn’t have to waste. But perhaps he has no choice. He refuses the sacred cactus 
and sets off toward the mountains. As he leaves the settlement behind,
he sees a group approaching. He recognizes them as highlanders
by their llamas. He dashes toward their shaman. Barely pausing to say hello, 
he offers him hematite, dried seaweed, and empty shells to grind up for lime
and chew with coca leaves. In return, the other shaman 
gives him the precious cinnabar. With the key to his ritual in hand, Quexo heads home to the temple 
of the fisherman in hopes of turning the tide.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Quexo lived in a__________
Options: A. Farming village, B. Fishing village, C. Herding village, D. Desert
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the village shaman in the story? Options: A. Quexo, B. The Fisherman, C. The Shaman of the Andes, D. The High Mountain Shaman Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary reason for Quexo's concern in the story? Options: A. The winds have died, and the fish have dwindled., B. The storms are approaching, and the villagers are not prepared., C. The villagers are not harvesting enough shellfish and sea urchins., D. The sacred cactus drink is not available. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the significance of the hematite in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for cinnabar., B. It is a key ingredient in the sacred cactus drink., C. It is a symbol of Quexo's status as a shaman., D. It is used to ward off the storms. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of Quexo's ritual? Options: A. To celebrate the beginning of the season of abundance., B. To ward off the storms and ensure a good harvest., C. To trade goods with the villagers., D. To become a shaman. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the role of the women in the story? Options: A. They are the leaders of the village., B. They are the ones who handle trade transactions., C. They are the ones who harvest shellfish and sea urchins., D. They are the ones who prepare the sacred cactus drink. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why is Quexo able to trade with the highland shaman? Options: A. Because he is a highland shaman himself., B. Because he has the sacred cactus drink., C. Because he has the hematite., D. Because he is a man and an exception to the rule. Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the significance of the cinnabar in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for other goods., B. It is a key ingredient in the sacred cactus drink., C. It is a symbol of Quexo's status as a shaman., D. It is used to ward off the storms. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the danger of Quexo's journey to the mountains? Options: A. It is a long and difficult journey., B. It is a journey that takes five days., C. It is a journey that takes him away from the village., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the result of Quexo's ritual? Options: A. The storms are still approaching., B. The fish have increased in number., C. The villagers are still preparing for the festival., D. The tide is turned, and the storms are warded off. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the significance of Quexo's role as a shaman? Options: A. It is a role that is limited to men., B. It is a role that is limited to women., C. It is a role that is flexible and allows for ambiguity., D. It is a role that is not important in the story. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the temple of the fisherman, 
Quexo, the village shaman, looks out over the ocean and frowns. It’s a still morning–
unusually still, and the lack of wind is the latest 
in a series of troubling signs. The year is 1400 BCE. Quexo’s village sits in the dusty, 
treeless desert between the towering Andes 
and Pacific Ocean. The villagers live off the sea, 
harvesting reeds, drying them in the sun, 
and using them to build fishing boats. Every day in the summer, the men set out on these boats
to hunt shark and other fish while the women harvest 
shellfish and sea urchins. In winter, storms bring powerful waves,
which cross the vast ocean unobstructed to detonate on these shores. Most years, Quexo’s village catches 
more than enough fish. But this year, the winds have died 
and the fish have dwindled. Quexo has seen this pattern before: the fish disappear, 
then the violent rains arrive, causing flash floods that dissolve 
mud bricks and wash away settlements. He needs to stop the bad weather 
before the storms come— his only hope is a special ritual 
he’s been planning. Quexo spends much less time
in the ocean than the other villagers. He became a shaman after seeing 
a sign in the sea one morning— like his father and grandfather
before him. This morning, he walks to the nearby sacred mountain 
as the sun rises. There, he gathers ceremonial cactus 
and herbs like “horse tail,” “stonebreaker," and valerian, 
along with the mineral hematite. Back in the village, 
everyone is preparing to leave for a religious festival 
at a large temple inland. The festival marks the beginning of what
is usually the season of abundance, but with the signs pointing to storms,
Quexo isn’t feeling too celebratory. Whole families travel to the festival,
where they camp for a few days. They’ve packed seaweed, carved bones,
gourd bowls, reed mats, and other goods to trade 
in the market around the temple. Quexo inspects the goods to make 
sure everything is of the finest quality. He brings the herbs he gathered 
to trade for cinnabar, a mineral that comes 
from the highlands in the Andes. He needs cinnabar for his ritual 
to ward off the storms. Around lunchtime, the sprawling 
temple rises out of the desert ahead. People have come from all along 
the coast and the foothills. The women handle trade transactions—
they’re looking for cotton and ceramics. Men aren’t usually allowed 
to do the trading, but shamans are an exception. Though Quexo is a man, during rituals 
he becomes half man, half woman, and this ambiguity makes his role 
more flexible outside ceremonies too. Quexo can’t find any cinnabar 
in the market, so he heads to the main temple, dodging children playing in the plaza. He puts on his ceremonial garb: 
red face paint, earrings, and a necklace of shark’s teeth
and vertebrae. Inside, the ceremonies 
are already underway, and the shamans have drunk
the sacred cactus drink. Many of them are Quexo’s friends 
from festivals over the years, but he doesn’t see the mountain shamans 
who would have cinnabar. He begins to panic. If the highland shamans don’t show up, his only option will be to make 
the long walk into the mountains. It’s a dangerous journey 
that takes five days, precious time he doesn’t have to waste. But perhaps he has no choice. He refuses the sacred cactus 
and sets off toward the mountains. As he leaves the settlement behind,
he sees a group approaching. He recognizes them as highlanders
by their llamas. He dashes toward their shaman. Barely pausing to say hello, 
he offers him hematite, dried seaweed, and empty shells to grind up for lime
and chew with coca leaves. In return, the other shaman 
gives him the precious cinnabar. With the key to his ritual in hand, Quexo heads home to the temple 
of the fisherman in hopes of turning the tide.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The story refers to a potential___________ about to occur in the region
Options: A. Storms, rains and floods, B. War, C. Earthquake, D. Tsunami
Correct Option: A

Question 7: What is the significance of the cinnabar in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for other goods., B. It is a key ingredient in the sacred cactus drink., C. It is a symbol of Quexo's status as a shaman., D. It is used to ward off the storms. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the danger of Quexo's journey to the mountains? Options: A. It is a long and difficult journey., B. It is a journey that takes five days., C. It is a journey that takes him away from the village., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the result of Quexo's ritual? Options: A. The storms are still approaching., B. The fish have increased in number., C. The villagers are still preparing for the festival., D. The tide is turned, and the storms are warded off. Correct Option: D

At the temple of the fisherman, 
Quexo, the village shaman, looks out over the ocean and frowns. It’s a still morning–
unusually still, and the lack of wind is the latest 
in a series of troubling signs. The year is 1400 BCE. Quexo’s village sits in the dusty, 
treeless desert between the towering Andes 
and Pacific Ocean. The villagers live off the sea, 
harvesting reeds, drying them in the sun, 
and using them to build fishing boats. Every day in the summer, the men set out on these boats
to hunt shark and other fish while the women harvest 
shellfish and sea urchins. In winter, storms bring powerful waves,
which cross the vast ocean unobstructed to detonate on these shores. Most years, Quexo’s village catches 
more than enough fish. But this year, the winds have died 
and the fish have dwindled. Quexo has seen this pattern before: the fish disappear, 
then the violent rains arrive, causing flash floods that dissolve 
mud bricks and wash away settlements. He needs to stop the bad weather

he’s been planning. Quexo spends much less time
in the ocean than the other villagers. He became a shaman after seeing 
a sign in the sea one morning— like his father and grandfather
before him. This morning, he walks to the nearby sacred mountain 
as the sun rises. There, he gathers ceremonial cactus 
and herbs like “horse tail,” “stonebreaker," and valerian, 
along with the mineral hematite. Back in the village, 
everyone is preparing to leave for a religious festival 
at a large temple inland. The festival marks the beginning of what
is usually the season of abundance, but with the signs pointing to storms,
Quexo isn’t feeling too celebratory. Whole families travel to the festival,
where they camp for a few days. They’ve packed seaweed, carved bones,
gourd bowls, reed mats, and other goods to trade 
in the market around the temple. Quexo inspects the goods to make 
sure everything is of the finest quality. He brings the herbs he gathered 
to trade for cinnabar, a mineral that comes 
from the highlands in the Andes. He needs cinnabar for his ritual 
to ward off the storms. Around lunchtime, the sprawling 
temple rises out of the desert ahead. People have come from all along 
the coast and the foothills. The women handle trade transactions—
they’re looking for cotton and ceramics. Men aren’t usually allowed 
to do the trading, but shamans are an exception. Though Quexo is a man, during rituals 
he becomes half man, half woman, and this ambiguity makes his role 
more flexible outside ceremonies too. Quexo can’t find any cinnabar 
in the market, so he heads to the main temple, dodging children playing in the plaza. He puts on his ceremonial garb: 
red face paint, earrings, and a necklace of shark’s teeth
and vertebrae. Inside, the ceremonies 
are already underway, and the shamans have drunk
the sacred cactus drink. Many of them are Quexo’s friends 
from festivals over the years, but he doesn’t see the mountain shamans 
who would have cinnabar. He begins to panic. If the highland shamans don’t show up, his only option will be to make 
the long walk into the mountains. It’s a dangerous journey 
that takes five days, precious time he doesn’t have to waste. But perhaps he has no choice. He refuses the sacred cactus 
and sets off toward the mountains. As he leaves the settlement behind,
he sees a group approaching. He recognizes them as highlanders
by their llamas. He dashes toward their shaman. Barely pausing to say hello, 
he offers him hematite, dried seaweed, and empty shells to grind up for lime
and chew with coca leaves. In return, the other shaman 
gives him the precious cinnabar. With the key to his ritual in hand, Quexo heads home to the temple 
of the fisherman in hopes of turning the tide.

At the temple of the fisherman, 
Quexo, the village shaman, looks out over the ocean and frowns. It’s a still morning–
unusually still, and the lack of wind is the latest 
in a series of troubling signs. The year is 1400 BCE. Quexo’s village sits in the dusty, 
treeless desert between the towering Andes 
and Pacific Ocean. The villagers live off the sea, 
harvesting reeds, drying them in the sun, 
and using them to build fishing boats. Every day in the summer, the men set out on these boats
to hunt shark and other fish while the women harvest 
shellfish and sea urchins. In winter, storms bring powerful waves,
which cross the vast ocean unobstructed to detonate on these shores. Most years, Quexo’s village catches 
more than enough fish. But this year, the winds have died 
and the fish have dwindled. Quexo has seen this pattern before: the fish disappear, 
then the violent rains arrive, causing flash floods that dissolve 
mud bricks and wash away settlements. He needs to stop the bad weather 
before the storms come— his only hope is a special ritual 
he’s been planning. Quexo spends much less time
in the ocean than the other villagers. He became a shaman after seeing 
a sign in the sea one morning— like his father and grandfather
before him. This morning, he walks to the nearby sacred mountain 
as the sun rises. There, he gathers ceremonial cactus 
and herbs like “horse tail,” “stonebreaker," and valerian, 
along with the mineral hematite. Back in the village, 
everyone is preparing to leave for a religious festival 
at a large temple inland. The festival marks the beginning of what
is usually the season of abundance, but with the signs pointing to storms,
Quexo isn’t feeling too celebratory. Whole families travel to the festival,
where they camp for a few days. They’ve packed seaweed, carved bones,
gourd bowls, reed mats, and other goods to trade 
in the market around the temple. Quexo inspects the goods to make 
sure everything is of the finest quality. He brings the herbs he gathered 
to trade for cinnabar, a mineral that comes 
from the highlands in the Andes. He needs cinnabar for his ritual 
to ward off the storms. Around lunchtime, the sprawling 
temple rises out of the desert ahead. People have come from all along 
the coast and the foothills. The women handle trade transactions—
they’re looking for cotton and ceramics. Men aren’t usually allowed 
to do the trading, but shamans are an exception. Though Quexo is a man, during rituals 
he becomes half man, half woman, and this ambiguity makes his role 
more flexible outside ceremonies too. Quexo can’t find any cinnabar 
in the market, so he heads to the main temple, dodging children playing in the plaza. He puts on his ceremonial garb: 
red face paint, earrings, and a necklace of shark’s teeth
and vertebrae. Inside, the ceremonies

the long walk into the mountains. It’s a dangerous journey 
that takes five days, precious time he doesn’t have to waste. But perhaps he has no choice. He refuses the sacred cactus 
and sets off toward the mountains. As he leaves the settlement behind,
he sees a group approaching. He recognizes them as highlanders
by their llamas. He dashes toward their shaman. Barely pausing to say hello, 
he offers him hematite, dried seaweed, and empty shells to grind up for lime
and chew with coca leaves. In return, the other shaman 
gives him the precious cinnabar. With the key to his ritual in hand, Quexo heads home to the temple 
of the fisherman in hopes of turning the tide.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Local shamans, B. Traders living around the pyramids of the ceremonial centers, C. Shamans from the highlands, D. Women living in the upper highlands
Correct Option: C

**Question 3: What is the significance of the hematite in the story? Options: A. It is used to trade for cinnabar.**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
hello i am norman the pants the knight i must protect the short vows from the monster i will use the second of my protectors t ch some words are spelled with tch at the end and some have just a ch but they make the same sound so how am i supposed to know when to use my protector shield maybe this will help the vowel makes a short sound so it is weak it has no letter friend it is so lonely it needs protecting with tch here comes the monster attack go elsewhere monster this vowel is under the protection of tch all these words have lonely vowels that make a short sound so tch has been used to protect them where the vowel has a letter friend use ch this vowel makes a short sound but it is not on its own it has a letter friend so it just needs ch here comes the monster it has been frightened away all these words have vowels with a letter friend they end with ch remember where the vowel has a letter friend use ch where a short vowel has no letter friend then it needs protecting with tch now you know when to use tch and ch even though they make the same sound my work here is done

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fill in the blank. When a vowel makes a short sound and does not have a letter friend you should use ______ at the end of the word.
Options: A. -TCH, B. -CH
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the full name of the character in the transcript? Options: A. Norman the Knight, B. Norman the Pants the Knight, C. The Short Vows, D. The Monster Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what sound do words with 'tch' at the end and words with just 'ch' make when pronounced? Options: A. Different sounds, B. The same sound, C. No sound, D. A similar but distinct sound Correct Option: B
Question 3: What happens to a vowel that makes a short sound and has no letter friend in words? Options: A. It makes a long sound, B. It needs protection with 'ch', C. It needs protection with 'tch', D. It has a letter friend Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the primary role of Norman the Pants the Knight in the transcript? Options: A. To frighten away the monster, B. To protect the Short Vows from the monster, C. To befriend the monster, D. To defeat the monster Correct Option: B
Question 5: If a word ends with 'ch' and the vowel has a letter friend, what is the correct spelling to use? Options: A. 'tch', B. 'ch', C. 'tch' or 'ch', D. Neither 'tch' nor 'ch' Correct Option: B
Question 6: What can be inferred about the monster in the transcript? Options: A. It is friendly, B. It is fierce, C. It is a protector, D. It is a letter friend Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happens to the monster when Norman the Pants the Knight uses the correct spelling for words with vowels that make a short sound? Options: A. It becomes friendly, B. It is frightened away, C. It becomes a protector, D. It remains fierce Correct Option: B
Question 8: What can be concluded about the use of 'tch' and 'ch' in words? Options: A. They are interchangeable, B. They make the same sound, C. They are used for different purposes, D. They are not used in words Correct Option: B
Question 9: What happens to a vowel that makes a short sound but has a letter friend in words? Options: A. It needs protection with 'tch', B. It needs protection with 'ch', C. It makes a long sound, D. It has no sound Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about the character Norman the Pants the Knight at the end of the transcript? Options: A. He is still fighting the monster, B. He has finished his work, C. He is tired, D. He is hungry Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, options, and overall intent. Both questions address the rule for using 'tch' in words where a vowel makes a short sound and does not have a letter friend. The correct options in both questions also match, stating that such vowels need protection with 'tch'. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
i just forgot by mercer mare [Music] sometimes i remember and sometimes i just forget [Music] this morning i remembered to brush my teeth but i forgot to make my bed i put my dishes in the sink after breakfast but i forgot to put the milk away i almost forgot to feed the puppy but he reminded me i didn't forget to water the plants they looked fine to me i didn't forget to feed the goldfish he just didn't look hungry i'll do it now mom i got ready for school i even got to the school bus on time but i forgot my lunchbox mom brought it to school for me thanks mom after school i went outside to play in the rain i remember to put on my rain slicker but i forgot my rubber boots when i came inside for a snack i didn't forget to take my boots off i left them on because i was going right back outside i had cookies and milk i was just going to eat three cookies but i forgot to count them i didn't forget to shut the refrigerator door though i just wasn't finished eating yet [Music] when dad came home from work i was supposed to get his paper i didn't forget the puppy got it first i know it's time for bed i didn't forget of course i'll remember to pick up my toys while i'm finished playing with them [Music] i took my bath and remembered to wash behind my ears i didn't use soap but i didn't forget to i just don't like soap i guess i did forget to pick up my toys did i forget to turn off the tub too but there's one thing i never forget i always remembered to have mom read me a bedtime story and i always remember to kiss her good night [Music] you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fill in the blank. In the morning Little Critter remembers to brush his teeth, but forgets to _______.
Options: A. clean his room., B. make his bed., C. wash his face., D. eat breakfast.
Correct Option: B

you can find books to read yourself at ReadBrightly.com
See ya!

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
while you're having fun reading a comic book i'm having fun mopping the floor i'm not reading a comic book it's an art book these are some sketches by a japanese artist called hakuzai and i'm not really mopping the floor i drew a datatastic bird with a mop and you're on its back ah i just read about hokusai doing the same thing in japan a long long time ago wow i love it now you're on the bird's back you know what they call this an artistic happening just like i happened to do art while i was mopping the floor well usually there's a crowd and they watch the artist perform art as it's happening hocus i was famous for doing that for drawing a big bird with a mop and just like i did i'm dead happening he did all kinds of stuff hocus i was very daring and didn't like to follow the traditional way of doing things he was known as that crazy artist who broke all the rules in front of a lot of people he would do crazy things like paint two little birds on a tiny grain of rice whoa two little birds on a grain of rice yep sometimes he would paint with his fingers or toothpicks or both hands at the same time and one time he spread out hundreds of sheets of paper outside a temple square and everyone was wondering what he was up to he had a broom and a big bucket of ink and yep just like you he drew a big picture no one could tell what he was drawing because it was too big they could only see him running around making lines everywhere i can see what he painted a big picture of a funny looking guy that amazing huh yeah that's what he drew a giant portrait of the patriarch of zen buddhism let's go maddie let's go visit hokusai the daring artists that was exciting you were so unpredictable it was crazy ah yes crazy and unpredictable keep things interesting just ride the is a reminder of the divine energy and is seen as sacred so the mountain has more power than the way wow there's power everywhere in that painting it is not a painting it is a print it is a series of images layered one on top of another the first image is just the outline it is a printed from a wooden block that had first the drawing pasted to it then all the lines carved around to make a stamp over the picture then each color is printed on top from a different carved block one for each color starting from the lightest to the darkest it's like a coloring book look at this one too these guys are having a picnic these guys are having a nice relaxing time whoa a gigantic waterfall and they're right on the edge scary oh i find it a fun to be under the edge that is where one finds the endless flow of creativity well you must have found that float because this waterfall is very unusual yeah i can see the slow moving water and the fast falling water both at the same time that are crazy and it makes me really feel how big that waterfall is it flows down forever i just draw what i and big powerful water yeah just like the other prince of the big wave we are a part of the beauty and immense power of nature that surrounds us i can do that yeah i want to do it too i want to follow my own flow thank you hokusai your art is so magnificent how about the courage to ride that wave a while you're having fun reading a comic book i'm having fun mopping the floor i'm not reading a comic book it's an art book these are some sketches by a japanese artist called hakuzai and i'm not really mopping the floor i drew a datatastic bird with a mop and you're on its back ah i just read about hokusai doing the same thing in japan a long long time ago wow i love it now you're on the bird's back you know what they call this an artistic happening just like i happened to do art while i was mopping the floor well usually there's a crowd and they watch the artist perform art as it's happening hocus i was famous for doing that for drawing a big bird with a mop and just like i did i'm dead happening he did all kinds of stuff hocus i was very daring and didn't like to follow the traditional way of doing things he was known as that crazy artist who broke all the rules in front of a lot of people he would do crazy things like paint two little birds on a tiny grain of rice whoa two little birds on a grain of rice yep sometimes he would paint with his fingers or toothpicks or both hands at the same time and one time he spread out hundreds of sheets of paper outside a temple square and everyone was wondering what he was up to he had a broom and a big bucket of ink and yep just like you he drew a big picture no one could tell what he was drawing because it was too big they a worth any attention when i am 80 i will have penetrated the true essence of things and when i am 140 years old then every stroke i paint will be alive that a wow more alive than this that wave is flow of creativity well you must have found that float because this waterfall is very unusual yeah i can see the slow moving water and the fast falling water both at the same time that are crazy and it makes me really feel how big that waterfall is it flows down forever i just draw what i and big powerful water yeah just like the other prince of the big wave we are a part of the beauty and **Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. It becomes dark (or a shade)., B. It becomes light (or a tint)., C. It becomes too dark to see., D. Nothing happens.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main topic of discussion in this video? Options: A. Painting techniques, B. Color theory, specifically value, C. Visual Arts, D. Music theory Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term for the lightness or darkness of a color or hue? Options: A. Hue, B. Tint, C. Shade, D. Value Correct Option: D
Question 3: What happens when you add black to a color? Options: A. It becomes lighter, B. It remains the same, C. It becomes darker, resulting in a shade, D. It changes its hue Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the result of mixing white and black? Options: A. A shade, B. A tint, C. A tone, D. Gray Correct Option: D
Question 5: How do you create a tone? Options: A. By adding white to a color, B. By adding black to a color, C. By adding gray to a color, D. By mixing two colors Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the effect of adding gray to a color? Options: A. It becomes lighter, B. It becomes darker, C. It creates a tone and remains the same in value, D. It creates a shade Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the term for a color that is created by adding white to another color? Options: A. Shade, B. Tint, C. Tone, D. Hue Correct Option: B
Question 8: How do you create a gradient? Options: A. By mixing two colors, B. By lining up colors from light to dark, C. By adding gray to a color, D. By adding black to a color Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the purpose of experimenting with paints to create shades, tones, and tints? Options: A. To practice painting techniques, B. To create a specific color, C. To understand the concept of value and its relationship with tints and shades, D. To create a gradient Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] hey everybody squeaks and i were just out for a walk and sqweek's found a bunch of lucky pennies for his lucky penny collection he's pretty excited oh yeah squeaks some of the pennies are new and shiny but some of them are kind of grimy and dull i wonder if there's a way that we can clean them up before we add them to your collection i think this calls for an experiment okay we've gathered a few things that i think might help us clean our pennies if you want to do the experiment with us here's what you'll need first you'll need to grab a grown-up and find five dull pennies then you'll need a little bit of dish soap some brown cola vinegar a teaspoon of salt lemon juice and ketchup finally you'll need five cups to fill with our different cleaners fill one cup with dish soap and a little water fill the next cup with some brown cola next combine the vinegar and salt into another cup and put some lemon juice in the next one and finally squirt a little bit of ketchup in the last one okay we're all set up here but before we put any of the pennies in the cups what do you think is going to happen ah squeak says that he thinks the soap and water will work the best since we use soap to clean lots of things cola stains things if you spill it so i'm not sure it will clean these pennies very well and ketchup i don't think that one will work at all i think the vinegar and salt will work the best because some cleaning solutions are made with vinegar okay now we're ready to put the pennies in we'll let them sit for five minutes or until you start to see some of the pennies getting shiny i think they're ready let's rinse them off and take a look hmm the penny that was in the soap and water doesn't look any different to me it was a good guess though squeaks let's look at the penny that was in the cola wow it's a lot shinier than i thought it would be and it's a lot cleaner than the soap and water penny ooh the penny from the lemon juice is even more shiny and the penny from the vinegar and salt is the shiniest of all and the penny from the ketchup whoa it's even shiny too that's awesome now we have our results but why did some of our pennies get really clean and some of them didn't well pennies are made of a metal called copper over time the copper combines with the oxygen in the air to make that dark coating on the outside that dark stuff is called copper oxide and it isn't shiny like copper is which is why the penny looks less shiny but under that dull layer of copper oxide there's still shiny copper to make the penny shiny again we need to use things that can dissolve or get rid of the copper oxide so how do you dissolve that dark coating well you can use something called an acid acids are great at dissolving lots of things including copper oxide and one thing that all the clean pennies have in common is that they were in stuff that was really acidic or had lots of acid you can tell that a food is acidic because it tastes really sour lemons are acidic and they're super sour that explains why the lemon juice cleaned the pennies so well vinegar is an acid too which is why it tastes kind of sour and eventually it would have cleaned the penny off all on its own but when you add salt to vinegar it turns into an even stronger acid that cleans the penny really fast the ketchup works because it has salt and vinegar in it it's also made from tomatoes which are really acidic too so that's why it cleaned the penny so well cola has lots of acidic ingredients added to it which is why it cleaned the penny and it's also why you should brush your teeth after drinking it because acid can hurt your teeth and cause cavities water and dish soap aren't very acidic at all so the dark coating of copper oxide didn't dissolve and the penny stayed dull you can try this experiment at home with lots of different things try soaking the penny in different kinds of juices or even coffee or tea there are so many possibilities and the best part is that you'll have lots of cool shiny pennies when you're done squeaks what do you say we clean up the rest of our pennies for a collection thanks for joining us for today's experiment and thanks to google making science for helping us make this episode do you have any questions about today's experiment let us know leave a comment down below or send us an email to kids scishow.com thanks for joining us and we'll see you next time here at the fort [Music]

Question 4: What is the main reason why some pennies are dull and not shiny? Options: A. Because they are made of a different metal, B. Because they have been cleaned too many times, C. Because they have a layer of copper oxide on them, D. Because they have been exposed to too much sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is an acid, according to the transcript? Options: A. A type of metal, B. A type of liquid that is used to clean things, C. A substance that is great at dissolving lots of things, including copper oxide, D. A type of food that is sweet Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did the ketchup work well in cleaning the penny? Options: A. Because it has a lot of sugar in it, B. Because it has a lot of salt in it, C. Because it has a combination of salt, vinegar, and acidic tomatoes, D. Because it has a lot of water in it Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the substance that is dissolved by acids, according to the transcript? Options: A. Copper oxide, B. Salt, C. Water, D. Ketchup Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why should you brush your teeth after drinking cola, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because it has a lot of sugar in it, B. Because it has a lot of acid in it, C. Because it has a lot of water in it, D. Because it has a lot of salt in it Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why did the penny that was soaked in soap and water not get clean? Options: A. Because the soap was not strong enough, B. Because the water was not hot enough, C. Because soap and water are not very acidic, D. Because the penny was not soaked long enough Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main idea of the experiment described in the transcript? Options: A. To test the strength of different cleaning solutions, B. To compare the effectiveness of different materials in cleaning pennies, C. To show how acids can dissolve copper oxide and clean pennies, D. To grow plants in different environments Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: Why did the penny that was soaked in soap and water not get clean? Options: A. Because the soap was not strong enough, B. Because the water was not hot enough, C. Because soap and water are not very acidic, D. Because the penny was not soaked long enough Correct Option: C.

However, the question type is different (True/False vs Multiple Choice), but the content and intent are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks if the penny in the soap and water was the shiniest (which is false), while the generated MCQ asks why the penny in the soap and water did not get clean, with the correct answer being that soap and water are not very acidic.

If I had to choose an index, I would choose Question 9 (Index 9), but please note that the question type is different.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] hey everybody squeaks and i were just out for a walk and sqweek's found a bunch of lucky pennies for his lucky penny collection he's pretty excited oh yeah squeaks some of the pennies are new and shiny but some of them are kind of grimy and dull i wonder if there's a way that we can clean them up before we add them to your collection i think this calls for an experiment okay we've gathered a few things that i think might help us clean our pennies if you want to do the experiment with us here's what you'll need first you'll need to grab a grown-up and find five dull pennies then you'll need a little bit of dish soap some brown cola vinegar a teaspoon of salt lemon juice and ketchup finally you'll need five cups to fill with our different cleaners fill one cup with dish soap and a little water fill the next cup with some brown cola next combine the vinegar and salt into another cup and put some lemon juice in the next one and finally squirt a little bit of ketchup in the last one okay we're all set up here but before we put any of the pennies in the cups what do you think is going to happen ah squeak says that he thinks the soap and water will work the best since we use soap to clean lots of things cola stains things if you spill it so i'm not sure it will clean these pennies very well and ketchup i don't think that one will work at all i think the vinegar and salt will work the best because some cleaning solutions are made with vinegar okay now we're ready to put the pennies in we'll let them sit for five minutes or until you start to see some of the pennies getting shiny i think they're ready let's rinse them off and take a look hmm the penny that was in the soap and water doesn't look any different to me it was a good guess though squeaks let's look at the penny that was in the cola wow it's a lot shinier than i thought it would be and it's a lot cleaner than the soap and water penny ooh the penny from the lemon juice is even more shiny and the penny from the vinegar and salt is the shiniest of all and the penny from the ketchup whoa it's even shiny too that's awesome now we have our results but why did some of our pennies get really clean and some of them didn't well pennies are made of a metal called copper over time the copper combines with the oxygen in the air to make that dark coating on the outside that dark stuff is called copper oxide and it isn't shiny like copper is which is why the penny looks less shiny but under that dull layer of copper oxide there's still shiny copper to make the penny shiny again we need to use things that can dissolve or get rid of the copper oxide so how do you dissolve that dark coating well you can use something called an acid acids are great at dissolving lots of things including copper oxide and one thing that all the clean pennies have in common is that they were in stuff that was really acidic or had lots of acid you can tell that a food is acidic because it tastes really sour lemons are acidic and they're super sour that explains why the lemon juice cleaned the pennies so well vinegar is an acid too which is why it tastes kind of sour and eventually it would have cleaned the penny off all on its own but when you add salt to vinegar it turns into an even stronger acid that cleans the penny really fast the ketchup works because it has salt and vinegar in it it's also made from tomatoes which are really acidic too so that's why it cleaned the penny so well cola has lots of acidic ingredients added to it which is why it cleaned the penny and it's also why you should brush your teeth after drinking it because acid can hurt your teeth and cause cavities water and dish soap aren't very acidic at all so the dark coating of copper oxide didn't dissolve and the penny stayed dull you can try this experiment at home with lots of different things try soaking the penny in different kinds of juices or even coffee or tea there are so many possibilities and the best part is that you'll have lots of cool shiny pennies when you're done squeaks what do you say we clean up the rest of our pennies for a collection thanks for joining us for today's experiment and thanks to google making science for helping us make this episode do you have any questions about today's experiment let us know leave a comment down below or send us an email to kids scishow.com thanks for joining us and we'll see you next time here at the fort [Music]

Correct Option: C

a few things that i think might help us clean our pennies if you want to do the experiment with us here's what you'll need first you'll need to grab a grown-up and find five dull pennies then you'll need a little bit of dish soap some brown cola vinegar a teaspoon of salt lemon juice and ketchup finally you'll need five cups to fill with our different cleaners fill one cup with dish soap and a little water fill the next cup with some brown cola next combine the vinegar and salt into another cup and put some lemon juice in the next one and finally squirt a little bit of ketchup in the last soap to clean lots of things cola stains things if you spill it so i'm not sure it will clean these pennies very well and ketchup i don't think that one will work at all i think the vinegar and salt and some of them didn't well pennies are made of a metal called copper over time the copper combines with the oxygen in the air to make that dark coating on the outside that dark stuff is called copper oxide and it isn't shiny like copper is which is why the penny looks less shiny but under that dull layer of copper oxide there's still shiny copper to make the penny shiny again we need to use things that can dissolve or get rid of the copper oxide so how do you dissolve that dark coating well you can use something called an acid acids are great at dissolving lots of things including copper oxide and one thing that all the clean pennies have in common is that they were in stuff that was really acidic or had lots of acid you can tell that a food is acidic because it tastes really sour lemons are acidic and they're super sour that explains why the lemon juice cleaned the pennies so well vinegar is an acid too which is why it tastes kind of sour and eventually it would have cleaned the penny off all on its own but when you add salt to vinegar it turns into an even stronger acid that cleans the penny really fast the ketchup works because it has salt and vinegar in it it's also brush your teeth after drinking it because acid can hurt your teeth and cause cavities water and dish soap aren't very acidic at all so the dark coating of copper oxide didn't dissolve and the penny stayed dull you can try this experiment at home with lots of different things try soaking the penny in different kinds of juices or even coffee or tea there are so many possibilities and the best part is that you'll have lots of cool shiny pennies when you're done squeaks what do you say we clean up the rest of our pennies for a collection thanks for joining us for today's experiment and thanks to Options: A. carbon, B. oxygen, C. soda, D. acid
Correct Option: B

brush your teeth after drinking it because acid can hurt your teeth and cause cavities water and dish soap aren't very acidic at all so the dark coating of copper oxide didn't dissolve and the penny stayed dull you can try this experiment at home with lots of different things try soaking the penny in different kinds of juices or even coffee or tea there are so many possibilities and the best part is that you'll have lots of cool shiny pennies when you're done squeaks what do you say we clean up the rest of our pennies for a collection thanks for joining us for today's experiment and thanks to google making science for helping us make this episode do you have any questions about today's experiment let us know leave a comment down below or send us an email to kids scishow.com thanks for joining us and we'll see you next time here at the fort [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Acids help to dissolve things. Which of the following is NOT made up of an acid?
Options: A. ketchup, B. soap and water, C. lemon juice, D. cola
Correct Option: B

Because they have a layer of copper oxide on them, D. Because they have been exposed to too much sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is an acid, according to the transcript? Options: A. A type of metal, B. A type of liquid that is used to clean things, C. A substance that is great at dissolving lots of things, including copper oxide, D. A type of food that is sweet Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did the ketchup work well in cleaning the penny? Options: A. Because it has a lot of sugar in it, B. Because it has a lot of salt in it, C. Because it has a combination of salt, vinegar, and acidic tomatoes, D. Because it has a lot of water in it Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the substance that is dissolved by acids, according to the transcript? Options: A. Copper oxide, B. Salt, C. Water, D. Ketchup Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why should you brush your teeth after drinking cola, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because it has a lot of sugar in it, B. Because it has a lot of acid in it, C. Because it has a lot of water in it, D. Because it has a lot of salt in it Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why did the penny that was soaked in soap and water not get clean? Options: A. Because the soap was not strong enough, B. Because the water was not hot enough, C. Because soap and water are not very acidic, D. Because the penny was not soaked long enough Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main idea of the experiment described in the transcript? Options: A. To test the strength of different cleaning solutions, B. To compare the effectiveness of different materials in cleaning pennies, C. To show how acids can dissolve copper oxide and clean pennies, D. and shiny but some of them are kind of grimy and dull i wonder if there's a way that we can clean them up before we add them to your collection i think this calls for an experiment okay we've gathered a few things that i think might help us clean our pennies if you want to do the experiment with us here's what you'll need first you'll need to grab a grown-up and find five dull pennies then you'll need a little bit of dish soap some brown cola vinegar a teaspoon of salt lemon juice and ketchup finally you'll need five cups to fill with our different cleaners fill one cup with dish soap and a little water fill the next cup with some brown cola next combine the vinegar and salt into another cup and put some lemon juice in the next one and finally squirt a little bit of ketchup in the last one okay we're all set up here but before we put any of the pennies in the cups what do you think is going to happen ah squeak says that he thinks the soap and water will work the best since we use soap to clean lots of things cola stains things if you spill it so i'm not sure it will clean these pennies very well and ketchup i don't think that one will work at all i think the vinegar and salt will work the best because some cleaning solutions are made with vinegar okay now we're ready to put the pennies in we'll let them sit for five minutes or until you start to see some of the pennies penny from the vinegar and salt is the shiniest of all and the penny from the ketchup whoa it's even shiny too that's awesome now we have our results but why did some of our pennies get really clean and some of them didn't well pennies are made of a metal called copper over time the copper combines with the oxygen in the air to make that dark coating on the outside that dark stuff is called copper oxide and it isn't shiny like copper is which is why the penny looks less shiny but under that dull layer of copper oxide there's still shiny copper to make the penny shiny again we need to use things that can dissolve or get rid of the copper oxide so how do you dissolve that dark coating well you can use something called an acid acids are great at dissolving lots of things including copper oxide and one thing that all the clean pennies have in common is that they were in stuff that was really acidic or had lots of acid you can tell that a food is acidic because it tastes really sour lemons are acidic and they're super sour that explains why the lemon juice cleaned the pennies so well vinegar is an acid too which is why it tastes kind of sour and eventually it would have cleaned the penny off all on its own but when you add salt to vinegar it turns into an even stronger acid that cleans the penny really fast the ketchup works because it has salt and vinegar in it it's also made from tomatoes which are really acidic too so that's why it cleaned the penny so well cola has lots of acidic ingredients added to it which is why it cleaned the penny and it's also why you should brush your teeth after drinking it because acid can hurt your teeth and cause cavities water and dish soap aren't very acidic at all so the dark coating of copper oxide didn't dissolve and the penny stayed dull you can try this experiment at home with lots of different things try soaking the penny in different kinds of juices or even coffee or tea there are so many possibilities and the best part Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content.
